translated: The Sutra of Ananda Asking about the Auspiciousness and Inauspiciousness of Serving the Buddha
Translated by Monk An Shigao of the Later Han Dynasty
Ananda said to the Buddha, Some people who serve the Buddha attain wealth, nobility, and harmony, while others
suffer misfortune and do not have harmony. Why are they not the same?
I wish that the Heavenly Honored One would explain it for everyone.
The Buddha told Ananda:

If someone serves the Buddha, receives precepts from a wise teacher, believes exclusively without transgression, diligently practices, does not lose what is received, has a clear appearance, worships in the morning and evening, respectfully lights lamps, purifies offerings, does not violate the precepts, does not tire of the precepts, and is joyful in the heart;
they will always be protected by the gods and good spirits, and whatever they face will be harmonious and their affairs will increase a hundredfold;
they will be respected by the heavenly dragons, spirits, and the masses, and will certainly attain the Way in the future.
These good men and good women are true disciples of the Buddha.
There are people who serve the Buddha but do not meet good teachers, do not see the scriptures, and only receive the precepts.
They are shown to have the name of precepts, but are confused and do not believe, violate the precepts, sometimes believe and sometimes do not believe, and are indecisive.
They also do not have a respectful mind towards the scriptures and images, do not burn incense, light lamps, or pay homage, and always harbor doubts.
They become angry, scold, speak harshly, and are jealous of the virtuous, do not observe the six days of abstinence, and kill living beings with their own hands.
They do not respect the Buddha's scriptures, keep them in shabby boxes or among unclean clothes;
Or place them on the unclean bed of their spouse;
Or hang them on the wall without a respectful seat, no different from ordinary worldly books.

If the sick have doubts and disbelief, they call shamans to perform divination and sacrifices to evil spirits. The celestial spirits are far away and cannot provide good protection. Demons and ghosts increase day by day, and evil spirits gather at the door, causing decline and misfortune in all directions.
Or they come from evil ways in past lives and are sinners in this life. They are not disciples of the Buddha. After death, they will enter hell and be tortured.

Because of their sins, they are now declining and will suffer misfortune in the future. After death, they will go to evil paths and experience pain that is indescribable. All this is due to accumulating evil and unwholesome conduct.

Foolish people are blind and do not think about the causes and conditions of past lives, the retribution of the spirit, and the fundamental origin. They say that serving the Buddha leads to this decline.

Ananda again addressed the Buddha, saying:
If a person does not kill with their own hands, does not killing with their own hands mean there is no sin?
The Buddha said:
Ananda!
Encouraging others to kill is graver than killing oneself.
Why is it so?
It may be slaves, foolish and lowly people who do not know about sins and merits;

Or they may be pressed and threatened by the county officials, not acting on their own accord. Although they incur the crime, the circumstances and intentions differ, with varying degrees of severity.
As for instructing others to kill, knowingly and intentionally committing the crime, harboring foolish evil thoughts, taking life with one's own hands, without any compassionate heart;
Deceiving the Three Jewels, betraying the natural spirits, injuring living beings and cutting off life, the crime is no greater!
Enemies retaliate against each other, receiving misfortune for generations, without end.
In this life, one is not at ease, frequently encountering disasters and misfortunes;

After death, one enters hell, leaving the human form, and will fall into the animal realm, to be slaughtered by others. In the three evil paths and eight difficulties, for millions of eons, offering one's flesh to others, with no end in sight, causing one's body to suffer, eating grass and drinking from springs.

In this world, there are presently such animals, all due to their past lives when they became humans, acting violently and against the way, secretly harming and injuring life, not believing in this retribution.
From generation to generation, they become enemies and take revenge on each other. The spirit is the same, but the form changes. The sin is as deep as this.

As for the worldly mind, Buddhist disciples should not engage in divination, seek blessings, use talismans and spells, perform exorcisms, make sacrifices, or offer prayers. They should also not choose auspicious days or times.
Those who receive the Buddha's five precepts are meritorious people. In all their undertakings, they should inform the Three Jewels;

The wise understand the impermanence of life, and do not go astray even unto death. If one is good and follows the Buddha's teachings, one can attain the path to liberation from the world.
